author: Eric Wolff
title: New EPA chief treads softly, but signals big changes to come - POLITICO
text:
EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt greets employees at the agency's headquarters on Tuesday. | Getty New EPA chief treads softly, but signals big changes to come Share on Facebook Share on Twitter 
New EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt offered a conciliatory greeting Tuesday to employees of the agency that he frequently sued in his previous job as Oklahoma's attorney general — but he made clear he plans a sharp departure from the Obama administration in the agency's strategy. 
“Regulators exist to give certainty to those that they regulate," he told a group of about 100 agency employees. "Those that we regulate ought to know what we expect of them so that they can plan and allocate resources to comply. That’s really the job of the regulator, and the process that we engage in in adopting regulation is very, very important because it sends a message." Story Continued Below 
In his previous job, Pruitt had sued to block Obama's EPA rules on climate change and the reach of the Clean Water Act — regulations that the White House is expected to gut with executive orders in the coming days. 
Pruitt said the EPA would stop the "abuses that occur sometimes: Guidance through rulemaking, or using the guidance process to do rulemaking, or engaging in litigation — regulation through litigation, consent decrees that actually bypass the Administrative Procedures Act.” 
Pruitt also praised the founding fathers, who he said addressed the problems of their day but "didn't shirk their responsibility." 
He also used the meeting at EPA headquarters as a sign of how people can disagree and still be able to sit down and have a productive meeting. 
"They acted with civility," he said. "Civility is something I believe in very much."
